Status quo/trajectory: The salient, negative narrative (teen shot in face; pending felonies; leave of absence) favors recall proponents. With only days left, there’s limited time for sentiment to shift. Why not lower (i.e., why not near-certain recall): • Very small electorates are volatile; a few dozen votes can swing the outcome. • Some voters may view a recall as premature before the court case concludes, or oppose recalls on principle. • Colorado elections frequently use mail ballots, which can broaden participation and add uncertainty. What would move me upward (higher chance he retains): • Credible polling or public endorsements from respected local figures opposing the recall. • Evidence of high, broad turnout (beyond activist networks), or visible pro-Metz organizing. • Legal developments favoring Metz (e.g., charges reduced/dismissed or exculpatory information). What would move me downward (lower chance he retains): • Additional damaging facts, victim statements, or official condemnations. • Clear signs of strong recall GOTV and low general turnout. • Loss of institutional or community support (e.g., local civic groups urging recall). Given the high-salience controversy, base rates for local recalls, and the tiny, mobilization-sensitive electorate, I moderately favor the recall to succeed while allowing substantial uncertainty.
